description: From Middle English alarme, alarom, borrowed from Middle French alarme, itself from Old Italian all'arme! (“to arms!, to the weapons!”), ultimately from Latin arma (“arms, weapons”).

entries.meaning: A summons to arms, as on the approach of an enemy.
Any sound or information intended to give notice of approaching danger; a warning sound to arouse attention; a warning of danger.
examples: Sound an alarm in my holy mountain.

entries.meaning: Sudden surprise with fear or terror excited by apprehension of danger; in the military use, commonly, sudden apprehension of being attacked by surprise.
A mechanical device for awaking people, or rousing their attention.
examples: The clock radio is a friendlier version of the cold alarm by the bedside.

entries.meaning: An instance of an alarm ringing, beeping or clanging, to give a noise signal at a certain time.
examples: You should set the alarm on your watch to go off at seven o'clock.

verbs.description: alarm (third-person singular simple present alarms, present participle alarming, simple past and past participle alarmed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To call to arms for defense
(transitive) To give (someone) notice of approaching danger
(transitive) To rouse to vigilance and action; to put on the alert.
(transitive) To surprise with apprehension of danger; to fill with anxiety in regard to threatening evil; to excite with sudden fear.
(transitive) To keep in excitement; to disturb.
